statement:
If equilateral triangles are erected externally on the three sides of
any given triangle, then their centres are the vertices of an
equilateral triangle.

![image](napoleon)

If we embed the statement in the complex plane, the proof is a mere
calculation. In the notation of the figure, we can assume that $A=0$,
$B=1$, and $C$ is in the upper half plane. The hypotheses are
$$\label{eq:hyp}
\frac{1-0}{Z-0}=\frac{C-1}{X-1}=\frac{0-C}{Y-C}=\alpha$$ where
$\alpha=\exp{\pi i/3}$, and the conclusion we want is $$\label{eq:conc}
\frac{N-L}{M-L}=\alpha$$ where
$$L=\frac{1+X+C}{3}\qquad M=\frac{C+Y+0}{3}\qquad N=\frac{0+1+Z}{3}\;.$$
From (\[eq:hyp\]) and the relation $\alpha^2=\alpha-1$, we get $X,Y,Z$:
$$X=\frac{C-1}{\alpha}+1=(1-\alpha)C+\alpha$$
$$Y=-\frac{C}{\alpha}+C=\alpha C$$ $$Z=1/{\alpha}=1-\alpha$$ and so
$$\begin{aligned}
3(M-L)&=&Y-1-X\\
&=&(2\alpha-1)C-1-\alpha\\
3(N-L)&=&Z-X-C\\
&=&(\alpha-2)C+1-2\alpha\\
&=&(2\alpha-2-\alpha)C-\alpha+1-\alpha\\
&=&(2\alpha^2-\alpha)C-\alpha-\alpha^2\\
&=&3(M-L)\alpha\end{aligned}$$ proving (\[eq:conc\]).

**Remarks:** The attribution to Napoléon Bonaparte (1769-1821) is
traditional, but dubious. For more on the story, see .
